cluster_description: Cluster 7 — Very high herbaceous cover (mean herb_cover = 0.929), very low shrub and tree cover and minimal built cover; high NDVI (mean = 0.717). Plots are overwhelmingly herb‑dominated with almost no woody layers.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots are characterized by an extensive, continuous sward of short, regularly mown grass that forms the dominant herbaceous layer. Woody vegetation is sparse and restricted to scattered mature trees, with no conspicuous shrub layer within plots. Plots exhibit broad, open horizontal extent with long sightlines (>30 m) and show evidence of high-formal maintenance (regular mowing).

cluster_description: Cluster 5 — Very high large‑tree canopy cover (mean large_tree_cover = 0.707) with small_tree present, very low herb layer (mean herb_cover = 0.09) and minimal built cover; very high NDVI (mean = 0.845). Indicates closed, tall canopy dominated sites.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots classified as mature canopy woodland/parkland are dominated by a continuous, tall tree canopy producing a closed-woodland structure. Vertical structure is complex, with a well-developed understorey of shrubs and small trees beneath the overstorey, resulting in limited ground‑layer openness and sparse herbaceous cover. Visibility within plots is generally short to medium (within ~10–30 m), and open grassy gaps are uncommon, confined to small sheltered openings.

cluster_name: parkland / open grass with scattered trees
cluster_description: Cluster 3 — High herbaceous cover (mean herb_cover = 0.736) with low–moderate large and small trees (large_tree 0.09, small_tree 0.067) and very low built cover; high NDVI (mean = 0.797). Suggests open grass areas with scattered trees.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots are characterized by expansive areas of short, regularly mown grass punctuated by scattered mature trees, producing an open parkland structure with long sightlines (>30 m). Maintenance intensity is high (formal), with clear evidence of regular mowing. Visual clutter is minimal and plots show no visible paths, street furniture, litter or people, and no adjacent built infrastructure.

cluster_description: Cluster 4 — Moderate to high large‑tree cover (mean large_tree_cover = 0.351) with a measurable shrub and small‑tree layer and intermediate herb cover (mean herb_cover = 0.337); low built cover and high NDVI (mean = 0.805). Indicates canopy‑dominated stands with an understory.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots categorized as mature woodland with understory are characterized by a closed tree canopy overlying a well‑developed understorey of shrubs and small trees. Vegetation exhibits a dense vertical structure and limited sightlines (visibility < 10 m), indicative of canopy closure and substantial understorey cover. Plots consistently lack observable built infrastructure or people and display very low maintenance intensity, consistent with unmanaged or semi‑natural woodland stands.

cluster_description: Cluster 2 — High large‑tree cover (mean large_tree_cover = 0.391) combined with substantial small‑tree and shrub layers (small_tree = 0.238, shrub = 0.127) and moderate herb cover; low built cover and high NDVI (mean = 0.819). Represents structurally complex, multi‑layered woodland.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots assigned to the multi-layered mixed woodland type are characterized by a dominant tree layer with multiple standing trunks and a well-developed understorey comprised of small trees and dense shrub strata. Many plots exhibit a continuous or near-continuous canopy with thick undergrowth, producing limited within-plot visibility (short to medium distances). The ground layer frequently contains leaf litter and patches of herbaceous vegetation, including tall herbs in some plots, indicating vertical structural complexity across canopy, sub‑canopy and ground strata. Variation among plots ranges from closed, dense woodland with compact understorey to areas with more open understorey and grassy clearings, but overall structural complexity and co-occurrence of tree, small-tree/shrub and herb layers are recurrent.

cluster_name: built‑dominated with scattered vegetation (urban residential / hardscape)
cluster_description: Cluster 1 — Moderate herb and shrub cover (herb = 0.301, shrub = 0.126) but relatively high built cover (mean built_cover = 0.461) and low tree cover; lower NDVI (mean = 0.48). Indicates built/impervious‑dominated plots with scattered vegetation.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots are dominated by extensive impervious surfaces (wide paved areas such as parking courts, driveways and access roads), with vegetation restricted to scattered peripheral patches or small islands. Where present, vegetation is low in stature and discontinuous, typically short mown grass, small shrub stands or occasional isolated trees, producing generally low vertical structure. Visibility within plots is moderate (roughly 10–30 m) and plots are directly adjacent to residential buildings and road infrastructure. Maintenance regimes observed across plots vary between low–semi‑wild and moderate, with some plots showing recent mowing of grassy patches.

cluster_name: mixed shrub–tree vegetation (successional scrub / planted green space)
cluster_description: Cluster 8 — Intermediate herb cover (mean herb_cover = 0.521) with moderate shrub and tree layers (shrub = 0.122, small_tree = 0.152, large_tree = 0.157), low built cover and high NDVI (mean = 0.789). Indicates a relatively even mixture of herb, shrub and trees.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots assigned to this habitat type display a heterogeneous, multilayered vegetation structure characterized by a prominent herbaceous ground layer (ranging from short mown grass to tall herbaceous meadows) co-occurring with woody vegetation. Many plots contain an intervening shrub layer and a discontinuous tree component, producing a mosaic of herbaceous patches and shrub–tree assemblages. Visibility within plots is typically moderate (approximately 10–30 m), and management intensity is generally low to very low, with numerous plots showing no recent mowing. Built infrastructure is largely absent from the vegetated areas sampled, such that the habitat appears semi-natural to semi-wild across the surveyed plots.

cluster_description: Cluster 6 — Extremely high built/impervious cover (mean built_cover = 0.889), very low vegetation in all height classes and very low NDVI (mean = 0.295). Represents largely hardstanding/bare impervious surfaces.
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots are dominated by an extensive sealed, paved surface configured as marked parking bays within a wide vehicular-access area. Vegetation cover on plots is minimal and confined to peripheral trees and a bordering fence, while the internal plot surface is continuous hardstanding. Plots exhibit medium sight-lines (approximately 10–30 m) and low visual clutter, consistent with a clean, well‑maintained impervious surface.

cluster_name: vegetated residential / gardens with scattered trees
cluster_description: Cluster 0 — Moderate herb cover (mean herb_cover = 0.531) with low shrub and tree cover (large_tree = 0.119), intermediate built cover (mean built_cover = 0.266) and moderately high NDVI (mean = 0.7). Suggests vegetated plots within built contexts (e.g., residential gardens, green verges).
habitat_description_from_photos: Plots assigned to the vegetated residential/gardens class are dominated by short, regularly mown herbaceous turf forming contiguous lawn cover with sparse, scattered arboreal elements. Mature, solitary or widely spaced trees create an open canopy with little or no dense understory, producing medium-to-long visibility across the vegetated area. Vegetation is commonly juxtaposed with residential buildings at plot margins; overall maintenance intensity across plots is moderate to high.
